newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Brazil rejects World Bank criticism of Mercosur.
newsitem.headline: Brazil rejects World Bank criticism of Mercosur.

text.p: Brazil rejected World Bank criticism of the South American Mercosur customs union, saying a new study which branded the bloc as "artificial" and "protectionist" was out of date.

"The World Bank should be a little more rigorous in drawing up its analyses," Jose Botafogo, Undersecretary for Trade and Economic Integration at the Foreign Ministry, told reporters. A World Bank study found the four-nation bloc -- comprising Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay -- helped trade and investment among members but mostly benefitted sectors unable to compete elsewhere, like the auto industry.
Botafogo said the study, which appeared on Wednesday, did not take into consideration any developments after 1994 and as such was out of date.
"The period and and the products analysed refer to a phase that has been completely finished," he said.

Exports from non-Mercosur countries entering the union totalled $55.168 billion in 1995, up from $25.060 billion in 1990, "testimony to the open and non-exclusive nature of the bloc," a Foreign Ministry statement said.
The statement also challenged a criticism included the World Bank study that dynamic trade in capital goods had been restricted to within the Mercosur group.
In the case of Brazil, capital goods accounted for 18 percent of exports to Mercosur members, but 20.7 percent of exports to the United States, Canada and Mexico, it said.
Botafogo said existing barriers to free trade within Mercosur were consistent with World Trade Organization rules and that steps were being taken to match developed countries.
"This process of liberalization has to be done gradually to allow highly inefficient economies to turn into efficient ones," he said.
